verses.text: When the men of Israel saw what had happened, each of them rushed upon their enemies, and every warrior pursued them as far as Bethulia.
verses.comment: After Holofernes was slain, the Israelites seized the moment to attack the remaining Assyrians. The sudden reversal of fortune echoes other Old Testament battles where God intervened for His people (e.g., Judges 7:22). Note the active participation of all the warriors, showing a unity in defense of the holy people, paralleling spiritual warfare called for in Christian life.

verses.text: The Assyrians fleeing in terror ran down the mountain paths; those who remained in the camp were overtaken and slaughtered by the men of Israel.
verses.comment: The panic and defeat of the Assyrians recall moments when the enemies of God’s people were thrown into confusion (Exod. 14:27). Their terror reflects the result of divine justice, further highlighting God's hand in the victory and the protection granted to His chosen community.

verses.text: Then the Israelites sent messengers to all the villages and regions of the hill country, calling the people together to help them destroy the remainder of the Assyrian forces.
verses.comment: Israel’s unity is emphasized as messengers spread news to gather reinforcements, reminiscent of how God’s assembly responds collectively (Josh. 10:6). This communal action also hints at how spiritual battles call for the unified efforts of the faithful.

verses.text: Every able-bodied man joined the pursuit, and they overran the Assyrians and defeated them completely.
verses.comment: The total involvement of the community in the battle speaks to the necessity of every member contributing to the victory. This passage magnifies the importance of the communal and corporate nature of the people of God.

verses.text: Uzziah sent word to Bethulia: 'Gather the women together to see what God has done through the hand of Judith.'
verses.comment: Judith’s role recalls other women of faith such as Jael (Judg. 4:21) and foreshadows Mary’s unique participation in salvation history (Luke 1:46-55). God works through humble servants, elevating them for His purposes—showing the value of holy women in God’s plan.

verses.text: When everyone came together and saw Judith, they praised her and joined in giving thanks to God.
verses.comment: Judith was publicly honored, but the praise ultimately went to God. The people recognize that while God works through His servants, He is the source of all victory. This mirrors the biblical theme of giving glory to God through the faithfulness of individuals.

verses.text: Together, the women adorned themselves with garlands and joined in rejoicing before God, while Judith led the procession.
verses.comment: Liturgical celebration and processions are prominent in this verse, with Judith leading the community in thanksgiving. The image of garlanded women and worship prefigures future forms of sacred procession and worship, highlighting the role of women in communal religious life.

verses.text: All the men of Israel, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem who had come to witness God’s great deeds, honored Judith greatly.
verses.comment: Judith is honored among all of Israel and specifically by Jerusalem—significant because Jerusalem is the spiritual heart of God's people. This also points to how exemplary faithfulness is worthy of remembrance and reverence in the tradition of honoring saints for their fidelity to God.

verses.text: When they saw her, they all blessed her, declaring, 'You are the glory of Israel! You have done great things for our nation!'
verses.comment: Judith is called the 'glory of Israel', echoing the language used of Mary in Luke 1:48 and of other righteous women. This verse highlights how God raises up individuals for the salvation of His people, a pattern fulfilled in Mary’s unique role in Christ’s incarnation.

verses.text: All the people celebrated her deeds for many days, with songs of thanksgiving and offerings to the Lord.
verses.comment: The songs of thanksgiving and offerings link the victory to worship, showing that praise and sacrificial gratitude follow God’s saving acts. The community responds liturgically, demonstrating worship's role in expressing salvation.

verses.text: Judith distributed to the people the gifts Holofernes had given her, and everyone rejoiced exceedingly.
verses.comment: Judith’s sharing of plunder reflects biblical principles of charity and the communal sharing found in Acts 2:45. This act points to the ideal of generosity and unity among God’s people, and foreshadows the importance of almsgiving and tangible acts of mercy.

verses.text: When the festival had ended, everyone returned to their homes, but Judith remained honored in Bethulia for the rest of her life.
verses.comment: Judith’s lasting honor echoes the biblical praise of a virtuous woman (Prov. 31:31). Her enduring legacy testifies to the spiritual principle that those who serve faithfully will be remembered among the people of God.

verses.text: In every generation, her name was revered, and her story was told by all of Israel.
verses.comment: Her perpetual honor foreshadows the veneration given to those who play a unique role in salvation history. Her memory is sustained through the generations—an important detail supporting the spiritual practice of remembering God’s saints.

verses.text: Thus, Israel celebrated its victory over its enemies, and the people dwelt in peace.
verses.comment: The peace following Israel’s victory illustrates the deep scriptural promise that God’s deliverance brings lasting peace, ultimately fulfilled in Christ, the Prince of Peace (Isa. 9:6). The narrative completes the transition from conflict to harmony, emphasizing the eschatological hope for the faithful.
